 dimension of sp hilbert space
int n
 dimension of tp hilbert space and of the matrix

Static Private Attributes

static int ** t2s
 static list of dimension [n_tp][2] that takes in a tp index i and returns two sp indices: a = t2s[i][0] and b = t2s[i][1]
static int ** s2t
 static list of dimension [M][M] that takes two sp indices a,b and returns a tp index i: i = s2t[a][b]
static int counter = 0
 static counter that counts the number of TPM objects running in the program

Friends

ostream & operator<< (ostream &output, const TPM &tpm_p)

Detailed Description

Author:
Brecht Verstichel
Date:
23-02-2010

This class TPM is a class written for two particle matrices, it inherits alle the function from its mother Matrix, some special member functions and two lists that give the relationship between the sp and the tp basis.

Definition at line 24 of file TPM.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

TPM::TPM ( int  M,
int  N 
)

standard constructor: constructs Matrix object of dimension M*(M - 1)/2 and if counter == 0, allocates and constructs the lists containing the relationship between sp and tp basis.

Parameters:
M nr of sp orbitals
N nr of particles

Definition at line 24 of file TPM.cpp.

TPM::TPM ( TPM &  tpm_c  ) 

copy constructor: constructs Matrix object of dimension M*(M - 1)/2 and fills it with the content of matrix tpm_c if counter == 0, the lists containing the relationship between sp and tp basis.

Parameters:
tpm_c object that will be copied into this.

Definition at line 75 of file TPM.cpp.

TPM::~TPM (  )  [virtual]

destructor: if counter == 1 the memory for the static lists t2s en s2t will be deleted.

void TPM::constr_grad ( double  t,
TPM &  ham,
SUP &  P 
)

Construct the right hand side of the Newton equation for the determination of the search direction, the gradient of the potential:

Parameters:
t scaling factor of the potential
ham Hamiltonian of the current problem
P SUP matrix containing the inverse of the constraint matrices (carrier space matrices).

void Matrix::diagonalize ( double *  eigenvalues  )  [inherited]

Diagonalizes symmetric matrices. Watch out! The current matrix (*this) is destroyed, in it the eigenvectors will be stored (one in every column).

Parameters:
eigenvalues the pointer of doubles in which the eigenvalues will be storen, Watch out, its memory has to be allocated on the dimension of the matrix before you call the function.

TPM &  b,
SUP &  P 
)

The hessian-map of the Newton system:

Parameters:
t potential scaling factor
b the TPM on which the hamiltonian will work, the image will be put in (*this)
P the SUP matrix containing the constraints, (can be seen as the metric).

Matrix &  object 
) [inherited]

Definition at line 159 of file Matrix.cpp.

double TPM::operator() ( int  a,
int  b,
int  c,
int  d 
) const

access the elements of the matrix in sp mode, antisymmetry is automatically accounted for:

TPM(a,b,c,d) = -TPM(b,a,c,d) = -TPM(a,b,d,c) = TPM(b,a,c,d)

Parameters:
a first sp index that forms the tp row index i together with b
b second sp index that forms the tp row index i together with a
c first sp index that forms the tp column index j together with d
d second sp index that forms the tp column index j together with c
Returns:
the number on place TPM(i,j) with the right phase.

int TPM::solve ( double  t,
SUP &  P,
TPM &  b 
)

solve the Newton equations for the determination of the search direction,

Parameters:
t scaling factor of the potential
P SUP matrix containing the inverse of the constraint matrices (carrier space matrices).
b right hand side (the gradient constructed int TPM::constr_grad)
Returns:
nr of iterations needed to converge to the desired accuracy

Friends And Related Function Documentation

ostream& operator<< ( ostream &  output,
const TPM &  tpm_p 
) [friend]

Output stream operator overloaded, the usage is simple, if you want to print to a file, make an ifstream object and type:

object << tpm_p << endl;

For output onto the screen type:

cout << tpm_p << endl;

Parameters:
output The stream to which you are writing (e.g. cout)
tpm_p the TPM you want to print
